rComments: Very little content in the lectures. There is no exam in the class so marks are given through assignments and participation. Normally I wouldn't have an issue with this but assignments are very vague and he gives no feedback whatsoever on them. Makes it difficult to know what he is looking for which is a big deal when these make up the whole grade.

No final exam, grades are distributed through reading responses, participation in class, attendance to Nordic Studies talks and a final essay. Lectures are light (based on the readings) and he allows a lot of time for discussion of various topics.

Professor Beltran is far and away the best professor I've had at U of T. The guy is caring, funny, quick, mischievous as hell, and engaging. He turns subjects you don't care for whatsoever into semester-long passions and is always open to meet to answer questions. Do yourself a favour and enrol in one of his courses.

Professor Beltran is a funny man who knows a lot about European politics. Though he's a bit confrontational sometimes and his lectures can be a bit messy and disorganized, he's a nice guy who runs a pretty average course. He is VERY European though, so get ready for a Spanish accent and class starting 20 or 30 minutes after the hour.
